docs.lead_paragraph: The Government today issued new rules that require drug companies to conduct much wider testing of drugs in children, so the companies can write labels that provide detailed information to doctors and parents about the proper use of medications by children. The final rules, issued by the Food and Drug Administration, were a top priority for President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton but met strenuous objections from many drug companies, which said they were impractical and burdensome.

headline.main: F.D.A. WILL REQUIRE COMPANIES TO TEST DRUGS ON CHILDREN

docs.lead_paragraph: Many working Americans will pay 8 to 20 percent more for health insurance premiums next year, the sharpest price increases since the early 1990's. The rises in premiums follow several years of failed efforts by health maintenance organizations and other managed health care companies to stem the growth in medical costs, particularly the large price increases for prescription drugs, advanced surgical devices and techniques, and services to patients outside hospitals. Cost-cutting has also been thwarted by legislation in a number of states that prevents H.M.O.'s from restricting patients' access to specialists and diagnostic procedures.

headline.main: Employees Facing Steep Increases in Health Costs

docs.abstract: Many working Americans will pay 8 to 20 percent more for health insurance premiums next year, sharpest price increases since early 1990's; this follows years of failed efforts by health maintenance organizations and other managed health care companies to stem huge growth in medical costs; several states have enacted legislation preventing HMO's from restricting patients' acccess to specialists and diagnostic procedures; earlier efforts to raise rates were beaten down by big employers and purchasing groups; but now, after wave of mergers and acquisitions and departures of HMO companies from some communities, there is less competition and HMO's are finding it easier to raise prices to try to restore profits; some businesses are sharing increases with their employees, while others are asking employees to pay larger percentages of employer's premium costs; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although she spent much of her time in the thrall of delusions, Margaret Mary Ray wrote her last missive to her mother in what seemed to be a moment of clarity. She mentioned her love for her children, wrested so many years earlier from her care. She said she had tried, in her way, to be good to them. And she gave vent to her exhaustion and disillusionment, hinting that she understood how untenable her existence had become. ''I'm all traveled out,'' Ms. Ray, 46, said in the letter, which was written before her death on Oct. 5, but reached her mother, Loretta Duvall in Greenwich, Conn., when it was too late. ''I chose a painless and instantaneous way to end my life in the valley I loved.''

headline.main: Behind the Jokes, a Life Of Pain and Delusion; For Letterman Stalker, Mental Illness Was Family Curse and Scarring Legacy
